come up with (smth).definition: Think of a plan or solution to a problem.
examples: They {came} {up} with a plan to make the business more profitable.

count on (sb).definition: To have confidence in someone because you know they will do what you want.
examples: You can always {count} {on} Greg in a crisis.

cut down on (smth).definition: To eat or drink less of a particular thing, usually in order to improve your health.
examples: I’m trying to {cut} {down} on sugar.

deal with (smth).definition: To take action in order to achieve something, or in order to solve a problem.
examples: You have to be really patient when you’re {dealing} {with} boss.

depend on (smth/sb).definition: To be influenced or determined by something else.
examples: Whether or not we go to Italy for our vacation {depends} {on} the cost.
{Drink} {up} your juice, it’s time to go.

drop in.definition: To make a short visit to someone in their home.
examples: {Drop} {in} when you’re in the neighbourhood.

eat out.definition: To eat a meal in a restaurant, not at home.
examples: I really like {eat} {out}.

fall apart.definition: When something breaks or breaks into pieces because it is old or weak.
examples: My old sneakers are {falling} {apart}.

fall out with.definition: To argue with someone and stop being friends with them.
examples: He {fell} {out} with his wife over money.

figure out.definition: To understand something. To find the answer by thinking carefully.
examples: It took me some time to {figure} {out} the new software.

find out.definition: To get information about something because you want to know more about it.
examples: If you want to {find} {out} more, visit our website.

get away.definition: To go somewhere to have a holiday, especially because you need a rest.
examples: I just need to {get} {away} for a couple of weeks.

get by.definition: To have just enough money to pay for the things that you need, but nothing more.
examples: How can she {get} {by} on so little money?

get on (smth).definition: To go onto a bus, train, aircraft, or boat.
examples: I guess I {got} {on} the wrong bus.

get off (smth).definition: To leave a bus, train, aircraft, or boat.
examples: Call me when you {get} {off} the plane.

get along (with sb).definition: To like each other and be friendly to each other.
examples: I really {get} {along} with my wife’s brother.

get over (smth).definition: To begin to feel better after an experience that has made you unhappy.
examples: I’m {getting} {over} my allergy.

get together.definition: To meet in order to do something. Or spend time together.
examples: Do you want to {get} {together} at the weekend and go for a drink?

get up.definition: To wake up and get out of bed.
examples: I always {get} {up} at 7 on weekdays.

give up (smth).definition: If you give up a habit or give up something unhealthy, you stop doing it or having it.
examples: He {gave} {up} overeating after his heart attack.
I {went} {ahead} and arranged the camping trip anyway.

go by.definition: If time goes by, it passes.
examples: Things are going to get easier as time {goes} {by}.

go off.definition: If a warning device goes off, it suddenly makes a loud noise.
examples: The bomb {went} {off} at 5.45 this morning.
I really can’t {go} {on} living like this – I’ll have to find a bigger apartment.

go out with (sb).definition: To have a romantic relationship with someone.
examples: They’ve been {going} {out} for one and a half years now.

grow up.definition: To gradually change from being a child to being an adult.
examples: What did you want to be when you {grew} {up}?

hang out.definition: To spend a lot of time in a place or with someone.
examples: Let’s {hang} {out} later.

hang (smth) up.definition: To hang something, especially clothes, on a hook.
examples: {Hang} your jacket {up} and come on in.

heat (smth) up.definition: To make food hot so it can be eaten.
examples: I {heated} {up} a piece of pizza.

hit it off.definition: If two people hit it off, they become friendly immediately.
examples: I knew you would {hit} it {off} with Trisha.

hold on.definition: To wait for a short time.
examples: {Hold} {on}, I’ll get my coat.
I won’t {hold} you {up} if you’re in a hurry.
{Hurry} {up}! We’re gonna miss the train!
You have to {keep} {on} training. And you will get a point!

keep up.definition: To continue to do something, especially to work hard or to do good work.
examples: {Keep} {up} the good work!

lay off.definition: To stop employing someone because there’s no work for them to do.
examples: The company {laid} {off} 200 workers in November.
He’s {let} me {down} again.

lie in.definition: To stay in bed in the morning later than you usually do.
examples: I like {lying} {in} on a Sunday.

look after.definition: To take care of someone or something.
examples: Don’t worry, my mother will {look} {after} the kids.

look down on (smb).definition: To think that someone is less important than you
examples: She {looks} {down} on him because he doesn't have a job.

look for.definition: To try to find someone or something.
examples: Sam’s {looking} {for} a job at the moment.

look forward.definition: To feel excited about something that is going to happen.
examples: Are you {looking} {forward} to your vacation?

look through.definition: To read something quickly and not very carefully.
examples: I’ve {looked} {through} some magazines.

look up.definition: To look at a book or computer to find a piece of information.
examples: I {looked} {up} dark matter on the Internet to find out more about it.
He’s always {looked} {up} to his granddad.

make (smth) up.definition: To say or write something that is not true in order to deceive someone.
examples: Are you {making} that {up}?

make up.definition: To forgive someone you have argued with.
examples: We sometimes quarrel but we always {make} {up} soon after.

make up for (smth).definition: To provide something good to make a bad situation better.
examples: I studied extra hours to {make} {up} for the time I had missed.

mess up.definition: Spoil or damage something, or do something badly.
examples: Who has {messed} {up} my room?

mix up.definition: To confuse two people or things.
examples: They look so much alike, I always {mix} them {up}.

move in.definition: To begin living in a new house or area
examples: I’ve just {moved} {in}, so I don’t know anyone yet.

move out.definition: To stop living in a particular house
examples: I’ve been given a week to {move} {out}.

name after.definition: To give someone or something the same name as someone or something else.
examples: Jack was {named} {after} his grandfather.
I almost {passed} {out} when I saw him.

pay back.definition: To pay someone the money that you owe them.
examples: I’ll {pay} you {back} as soon as I get my next salary.

pay off.definition: If something you have done pays off, it is successful.
examples: All his hard work {paid} {off} in the end.

Pick on (smb).definition: To criticize, punish, or be unkind to a person often and unfairly.
examples: The other boys {pick} {on} him because he’s so small.

Pick (smb/smth) up.definition: To get or bring someone or something from somewhere.
examples: You have to {pick} {up} the kids from school.

Pick up.definition: To improve or increase after a bad period.
examples: Her career is beginning to {pick} {up}.
The work is really {piling} {up}.
Take an umbrella, it’s {pouring} {down}!

Pull down (smth).definition: To destroy a building because it is not wanted anymore.
examples: Our old school was {pulled} {down}.

Pull over.definition: To drive to the side of the road and stop your car, or to make someone else do this.
examples: A policeman {pulled} me {over} the other day.

Pull yourself together.definition: To become calm and behave normally again after being angry or upset.
examples: Just {pull} yourself {together}.

Put (smb) down.definition: To make someone feel stupid and unimportant by criticizing them.
examples: Stop {putting} me {down}.

Put forward (smth).definition: To suggest a plan, proposal, idea for other people to consider or discuss.
examples: We’ve {put} {forward} a number of ideas.

Put off (smth).definition: To delay doing something or to arrange to do something at a later time.
examples: I often {put} {off} doing my work.

Put on (smth).definition: To put a piece of clothing onto your body.
examples: I think I’ll {put} {on} a pair of jeans and a top.

Put out (smth).definition: To make something that is burning stop burning.
examples: The firefighters are still trying to {put} {out} the fire.

put up with (smb/smth).definition: To accept unpleasant behavior or an unpleasant situation.
examples: I can’t {put} {up} with it anymore.

Read up on (smth).definition: To read a lot about something because you will need to know about it.
examples: You might want to {read} {up} on it.

Rely on (smb/smth).definition: To trust on someone or something to do what you need them to do.
examples: I knew we could {rely} {on} you.

Rip off (smb).definition: To cheat someone by making them pay too much money for something.
examples: Tourists are often {ripped} {off}.

Run away.definition: To secretly leave a place in order to escape from someone or something.
examples: He {ran} {away} from home at the age of 15.
Guess who I {ran} {into} today!
